data.text: How to Protect the Bike from the Rain when Camping?

How do you protect your bike from the rain while touring? while camping, if it's raining outside: Do you leave the bike on rain? Or do you carry a tarp or cover to protect it? A tarp seems like a good idea but wanted to ask for opinions. Thanks
It's rain.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: That can otherwise cause rust and other issues. Water isn‚Äôt harmless.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: pretty harmless.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: I just use a cover for my Brooks saddle, but otherwise leave the bike out. As long as there‚Äôs no damage to the paintwork, the bike should be fine I think?
data.author: Anwen Ashworth

data.text: I just put a bag over the seat.
data.author: Al Niemeyer

data.text: Mine, being a folding bike goes in the tent.
data.author: Christine Roche

data.text: Rain at night is great, it cleans the mud off.
data.author: Guy Ladbrooke

data.text: Your bike is water soluble??
data.author: Mick Allan

data.text: obviously
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: Big Agnes Hotel tent. Bike goes in the garage üòâ
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: Mine was. Tubes rusted out from the inside. But I guess that was condensation from me living in the woods with it for over a decade.
data.author: Steven Offord

data.text: A plastic shower cap to protect the seat from rain., doubles up to rain proof helmet if its raining hardü§£Store it under the seat.
data.author: Jean Davis

data.text: I carry the rainfly from the Hennessy Hammock I used to have, and I cover up the bike even it it's not raining (and lock it up to a tree or post as well) not just because of the rain but also as "camouflage" and to discourage potential marauders, both human and otherwise, from snooping around.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: how did you like the Hennessey Hammock? Did you use it much. I have one but have never even opened it up, lol
data.author: Steve Cherry

data.text: I did like it quite well. I used it especially in Puerto Rico and Cuba. It is very well made, comfortable, with a good mosquito net, etc. However, it's not so good for colder climate, unless you develop and put in place insulating elements, and then on the other hand having to find rightly spaced trees or other things to hang it on is not so convenient depending on where you are. I therefore prefer my freestanding tent, but ideally both, to have the choice, even though it represents a bit of extra weight.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Left my bike out in a tropical downpour today. Felt a little bad while it was raining.
data.author: Martin Lim

data.text: I just remove the Brooks saddle and leave the rest in the rain.
data.author: Wan Sabri

data.text: My tent is large enough to house me and my Trike. Sure there‚Äôs a weight penalty however I deem the security and the weather protection to be worth it
data.author: Lachlan Johnson
Lachlan Johnson

data.text: which make size of rent is it?
data.author: Neil On Wheels

data.text: Mine is essentially a carbon copy of Loneriders‚Äô Mototent Weight does come in at 6kg~ and the rest of the dimensions are in the photo
data.author: Lachlan Johnson

data.text: But at a price of $300AUD as opposed to loneriders $700AUD, the protection it affords you and all your gear the weight penalty is worth it to me. It may not be for you but that‚Äôs where trail and error come in to play
data.author: Lachlan Johnson

data.text: 2man tent room enuff for u and your bike
data.author: Raymond Chatt

data.text: I use a camouflage small motorcycle cover. It folds up very small to carry.
data.author: Liz Fagel

data.text: I do this too. Only problem is finding the bike in the morning because it's camouflaged üòÖ
data.author: Tony Mitchelhill

data.text: I‚Äôve been curious of this exact question myself. Rust is weird pet peeve of mine. I like my gear to be in great condition, but luckily, my bike frame is aluminum. I‚Äôd like to turn all of my bolts in to stainless or Ti eventually
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: I was on a bikepacking trip where we were allowed primative camping. After we pitched our tents and collected wood for the fire, it started to rain. So we used our tarp to cover our bikes and went into our tents till the rain stopped. Duh the wood was wet and wouldn‚Äôt light. Next time cover the wood. Lol.
data.author: Bruce Peterson

data.text: I carry a cheap plastic cover, it's only about 200g and folds up quite small. I think of it as part of the bikes security as well.
data.author: Phil Metcalfe

data.text: I sleep in a hammock keep my bike underneith my tarp always wildcamp as much as possible
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Same.
data.author: Robert Crow

data.text: nice how long do you stay away from people usually i tend to only need a recharge once per 3 weeks to a month from the wall if im not carrying solar panels thats also how long i can do without restocking my supplies
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: I don't know how long I can stay away. I am married with three kids. I don't get more than two weeks at a time. Power use depends on if I need navigation or to stay in touch. Sometimes I need to be able to use my phone for Hotspot even out in the mountains. Pedalcell is a product I plan to get this year to handle battery charging.
data.author: Robert Crow

data.text: I have a Brompton which folds up and I put it in the tent with me
data.author: Steve Owen

data.text:
I like a little more space myself so this is my solution. https://www.nemoequipment.eu/product/dagger-ridge-porch/
Dagger‚Ñ¢ Ridge Porch Camping Tent ‚Äì NEMO Equipment
nemoequipment.eu
data.author: John Robert Zaums

data.text: I don't bikes are OK when wet
data.author: John Axson

data.text: Paintwork on a bike is the same as a car, it depends how much the user cares about it, you can't do much while your using it in the rain but when you get home wipe it down before putting it away
data.author: Danny Simmons

data.text: 1 put a cheap rain poncho over the bike.
data.author: Christie Ogden

data.text: The bike gets washed. I bring all the panniers in every night however.
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: When camping, I've seen people use a tarp for a tent and the bike acts as a part of the framing. Innovation is one of my favorite things about tour biking!
data.author: Ed Melby

data.text: It's pretty much water proof. Unless, it stands with its mouth open toward the sky. Then it drowns.
data.author: Robin Brodsky

data.text: I covered my bike and bags with my military poncho during my trans Am ride in 2003.. worked well for dew in the mornings as well as rain!! Plan to do the same again this summer.. use the poncho that is.. not the trans Am again!!ü§©ü§©ü§©ü§£ü§îüôè
data.author: Skip Hebert

data.text: do you have a picture to see how it looks?
data.author: Vanesa B Vizuete

data.text: I carried a poncho, which opened up to flat, I covered bike and packs with it, while I was undercover, or in tent, also any night, it kept me dry from dew, I could wear it while riding and expand the bottom out to cover me and bike, it was a very useful
data.author: David Atwell

data.text: Just a cover over the seat. Rain isn‚Äôt going to hurt it.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: So if your worried about rain what do you do when you ride and it rains? Don't worry about it.
data.author: Bill Dove

data.text: I carry a small plastic bag and cover the seat if it‚Äôs leather.
data.author: Heather Sims

data.text: It's a bike, it's meant to get wet.
data.author: Annie Mtb North

data.text: Poncho, seat cover
data.author: Dennis Peterson

data.text: I carry two ground covers/tarps. One for the tent. One to cover the bike. Also, I have a B17 saddle and cover it with the saddle cover that came with it. I stake down/tie down the bike cover.
data.author: Andrew Hill

data.text: Water is a bikes worst enemy. Keep it out of the weather as much as you can. Take it inside if you can. Wipe down and there are cleaning boxes that snap onto the chain you can run it through. (NEVER HOSE YOUR BIKE OFF!!!)
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: Only cover for the saddle.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: I don't mind the bike getting wet in the rain: I'll ride it when it's raining after all. But I'll wipe it down afterwards, and carry some wet lube for the drive train. It's my leather saddle that I'll protect with a cover, however.
data.author: David Law

data.text: Our problem was the dust/grit in the chain/gears after travelling on country/farm tracks.
data.author: Michael Woolaghan

data.text: - probably exactly what not to do‚Ä¶ a high pressure car wash will void the warranty on my internal 8 speed, but, I can‚Äôt imagine it‚Äôs terribly good for any hubs, bottom brackets, really anything related to bikes‚Ä¶ the bike isn‚Äôt meant for those intense pressures‚Ä¶ I usually wait ‚Äòtil I get home to give the bike a thorough, but gentle cleaning, taking off fenders, and other parts for careful cleaning‚Ä¶ Also, my LBS offers a complete tear down, clean, lube, re-build for about $125 if I‚Äôve really gone heavy on crushed limestone trails or the like, where very fine grit can get everywhere, but again don‚Äôt want to hit with a high-pressure car wash‚Ä¶ bikes are not made for that industrial of a cleaning‚Ä¶ MHO‚Ä¶
data.author: Howard Maher

data.text: : hello, yes not ideal, but carrying the kit necessary and time to do it properly, when away from home for a month, isn't worth it! The drive train was re-lubricated when dry.
data.author: Michael Woolaghan

data.text: My bike is not made of sugar. No problem if it gets wet!
data.author: Wim Verberne

data.text: I would never have thought of buying a purpose made rain cover but I saw one in the bike shop for just a couple of pounds. It has been incredibly useful and definitely keeps out the corrosion. I take it with me on tour and no longer care if I look like a nimby. It means the bike is always dry when I start in the morning and it takes up almost no weight/space. I would recommend.
data.author: Paul McMullen

data.text: we use large bbq.cover cheap and does the job
data.author: Gary Anderson

data.text: The bike stays inside the tent. I'm from California, and conditioned against theft.
data.author: Greg Lozaga

data.text: Chain wax, no cleaning if possible
data.author: Andreas Pfammatter

data.text: I always carry a tarp as it helps to protect my tent when it is tied to my rear bike rack. It also acts as another ground cover for my tent on rough ground and then as a bike cover for when it rains üëç
data.author: Marcus Study

data.text: The bike gets wet when you ride, maybe a plastic bag for seat especially if leather.
data.author: Steel Bikes

data.text: It just gets wet. They're made to be outside in all weathers.
data.author: Tony Jackson

data.text: My bike is 17 years old, it has seen rain, snow and hail. Never used a cover while camping, never even wiped it off after riding. I clean it thoroughly a few times per year. Never had issues with rust. I do use a saddle cover art night though, mainly because it's leather and because I don't like getting my bum wet ü§£
data.author: Jessica Kittle

data.text: If it rains, put your bikes in the tent. You sleep outside. Skin is waterproof!
data.author: Aldo Errico

data.text: It stays outside and gets wet, no problems so far. If there is an undercover part I'll utilise that.
data.author: Sarah Vickers
